thread.title: Who could replace Theresa May as Prime Minister? Here are the favourites

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Who could replace Theresa May as Prime Minister? Here are the favourites
text:
Who could replace Theresa May as Prime Minister? Here are the favourites If Theresa May is forced to resign this is who could replace her Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
Prime Minister Theresa May’s government is falling apart.
Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson and Brexit Secretary David Davis have both resigned.
And there’s no obvious way of uniting her party when it comes to Brexit, on which different Tory MPs have very different views.
It’s possible Theresa May will carry on as Prime Minister for a while longer.
But if she is forced to resign, who will replace her?
Assuming she quits before the next general election , the next Prime Minister will be another Conservative . That means they will be chosen by Tory MPs and party members.
Of course, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn might become Prime Minister before long, if Labour wins the next general election.
But it still seems likely that he won’t be Prime Minister immediately after Theresa May.
Polling company YouGov has been asking Conservatives who they want as their next leader, and here are the results: Sajid Javid Tory Home Secretary Sajid Javid (Image: BBC)
The most popular potential replacement for Theresa May is Sajid Javid, the Home Secretary and MP for Bromsgrove.
YouGov found 62 per cent of party members believed he would make a good leader.
Aged 48, he’s the son of a bus driver from Rochdale.
Mr Javid would be the first Asian Prime Minister and the first Prime Minister from a Muslim backround. Ruth Davidson Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson during a press conference at the Apex Waterloo Hotel in Edinburgh. (Image: PA)
The leader of the Scottish Conservative Party is popular with members.
She’s a liberal-minded centre-ground Tory who is having a baby with her same-sex partner. In the EU referendum she backed the remain campaign.
Ms Davidson comes across as likeable and more down-to-earth than some Conservatives.
YouGov found 61 of party members thought she would make a good leader.
The problem for the party is that she isn’t actually an MP, and instead is a member of the Scottish Parliament. She’d need to be an MP before she could become Tory leader. Jacob Rees-Mogg Jacob Rees-Mogg (Image: PA)
Backbench MP Jacob Rees-Mogg has never held a Government job.
But he’s extremely influential as chair of the European Research Group, which represents anti-EU Conservative MPs.
The Conservative MP has been called the “Honourable Member for the 18th century”, and some of his ideas do seem old-fashioned.
He’s got six children, but says he’s never changed a nappy because the family nanny does it instead.
He’s embraced Twitter but his first message to followers was in Latin, reading: “Tempora mutantur, et nos mutamur in illis”. It means: “the times change, and we change with them”.
And he once recited a 19th century poem in the House of Commons, somewhat to the annoyance of MPs who were trying to debate animal welfare.
YouGov found 59 per cent of party members thought he’d make a good leader. Boris Johnson Boris Johnson
The former Foreign Secretary would make a good leader according to 47 per cent of Tories.
But his role as one of the leaders of the “leave” campaign makes him a divisive figure.
For a long time, Conservatives thought Boris could reach the parts of the UK that other Tories could not. People liked him .
But he may not be as popular as he used to be. Jeremy Hunt Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt (Image: Getty Images Europe)
The new Foreign Secretary, Jeremy Hunt, is popular within the party.
And 49 per cent of members think he would make a good leader.
But he oversaw reforms to the NHS that made him very unpopular with some health service workers. Michael Gove
Environment Secretary Michael Gove has been Education Secretary and Justice Secretary.
He was a leader of the “leave” campaign in the EU referendum.
Nobody can deny that Mr Gove is smart. In person, he’s extremely likeable. Read More What will Brexit mean for jobs in the North East? MPs are in Brussels to find out Gavin Williamson
Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson, MP for South Staffordshire, was a vital support for Mrs May in his former role as Chief Whip.
However, he is said to have upset some Conservative MPs. And don’t forget Jeremy Corbyn Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn (Image: PA)
It seems unlikely that Theresa May will stay on as Prime Minister until the next election.
But if she does, the country will face a choice between giving the Tories under her leadership another term in office - or making Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn the next Prime Minister. Like us on Facebook
